pr_title: [haywardomnilogic] Replacement for Hayward Omnilogic Pool Automation Binding

timeline.bodyText: Please add @NonNullByDefault
timeline.author: cpmeister
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,32 @@

+package org.openhab.binding.haywardomnilogic.internal;
+
+/**
+ * The type to request.
+ *
+ * @author Matt Myers - Initial Contribution
+ */
+public enum HaywardTypeToRequest {

timeline.bodyText: Please add @NonNullByDefault
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: Why are you retrieving this from the properties instead of from the thing configuration?
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText:
The error logging level should be reserved for issues catastrophic enough to threaten the operation of openHab itself. An error in a binding shouldn't qualify for this. Please read the openHab coding guidelines for expected use of logging in bindings.
My general rule for logging levels is:

trace - used for normal expected execution paths
debug - used for unexepected execution paths, but well within normal operation
info - used for notable points in an execution path, like a milestone. (in openhab we try reserve this logging level for the core, so bindings should rarely ever call this.)
warn - used for notable unexpected execution paths that a regular user (not just a developer) should be notified of. Warnings should be used to indicate that something not-normal occurred and user intervention is required to resolve. Warnings do not indicate a failure to operate merely an abnormal condition of operation that can still be handled by the binding. Failures in binding operation should be indicated by changing the thing status to offline.
error - used to indicate catastrophic program failure. This should be used to indicate a catastrophic failure in openhab's ability to operate. A failure in a binding would never cause openhab as a whole to fail so a failure in a bindings should never log an error. Instead that failure should be indicated by changing the thing status.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: Can you ever have more than one heater with the same systemId? Or are systemIds unique for every device on the network?
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: systemID's are unique for every device controlled by the OmniLogix controller.
replies.author: matchews

timeline.bodyText: Heater doesn't have a chlorinator channel listed in the xml.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: How do you know you are parsing the data for the correct heater at this point? You seem to always choose the one at index 0.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: You should be returning a QuantityType here instead.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: Same here. But since you don't really know what type of Dimensionless unit you should be using here, you need to either pass that in to your function as well or make sure that you are only using Dimensionless for a certain type of unit (i.e. Percentage).
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: If pumps, heaters, relays, etc. are implicitly mapped to bodies of water, why not just make bodies of water a bridge type as well? That way you can more naturally represent the thing hierarchy as well as make it closer to how the omnilogic system represents them.
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: Some of these devices can be shared between two bodies of water.  For example a single heater is typically plumbed with valves to heat both the pool and spa.  The pump can be plumbed with valves to circulate the pool and/or the spa.
replies.author: matchews

timeline.bodyText: remove this
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: remove this line
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: use it or lose it
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText:

timeline.bodyText: Please include the exception message in the log.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: Are these used?
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
They are programmatically generated.  I deleted the constants.  Thx.

replies.author: matchews

timeline.bodyText: This if statement is redundant since the code above would return if !(status.equals("0")
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: Can this be removed?
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Can you fix the compiler warning about null value?
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Better create a custom exception for this as Exception catches also all RuntimeExceptions. Please check all try-catch blocks.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: Without the Exception catch, I get unhandled exception type exception compile errors.  Can you please elaborate on how to handle this?
replies.author: matchews

replies.bodyText: You can create a custom exception by defining a new class extending Exception. This new exception needs to be thrown by getMspConfig() and mspConfigDiscovery().
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Are you logging the stack trace by intention? Please check all.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: Can you please elaborate on what the preferred solution is here?  Thx.
replies.author: matchews

replies.bodyText:
This will only log the exception's message, which should be sufficient in most cases.
logger.warn("Exception during discovery scan: ", e.getMessage());
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You might want to include the exception's message in the details message.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText:
The log message could be removed, as the status update is already logged by the framework.
The state change originated by updateStatus() is logged to events.log. Including the status detail message.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: getBridge() returns null if the user configured the Thing via textual configuration and forgot to specify the bridge. You could set the Thing OFFLINE with an appropriate error message in this case. Please check all.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: Please do a null check instead of suppressing the compiler warning. Please check all.
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Please put all fields at the top of the class.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You could make this method abstract to avoid confusion why there's an empty method. By declaring it abstract everybody knows that it's supposed to be overriden.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You could store a local reference (variable) to getBridge() and do a null check on that to get rid of the compiler warning.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You could do a null check on bridgehandler to get rid of the compiler warning.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You could store bridgeHandler to a local variable and do the null check on that. Then, you can remove the null suppression on the class. Same for below.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Can these messages be replaced by using the debugger or by increasing the framework's log level? See point 4 https://www.openhab.org/docs/developer/guidelines.html#f-logging
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText:
If you make login() and getSiteList() throw HaywardException instead of Exception, you could catch HaywardException here. Catching only Exception would catch also all RuntimeExceptions.
Please check all.
timeline.author: fwolter
fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You could add a null suppression to this class to prevent this null warning.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Are you sure these properties are always set? What happens if the user adds the Thing manually?
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: This exception is thrown when OH is shut-down. That means the current operation should be finished as fast as possible and no further operations should be done. You can achieve this by not catching the exception here but throw the InterruptedException and catch it at the highest level you can.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: Most of the Hayward Thing Handlers handleCommand methods call the bridge.httpXmlResponse.  The handleCommand methods all ultimately override the ThingHandler.handleCommand method.  I'm not seeing a way to throw an exception on an override which means I can only throw this up one level, but then would need to catch it in most of the thing handler handle command methods.  Let me know if I'm missing something obvious.  Thanks.
replies.author: matchews

replies.bodyText: You're right, the exception can't be thrown any higher than in handleCommand(). That should be sufficient in your case as you can exit handlerCommand() immediately if you catch InterruptedException there.
replies.author: fwolter

timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: See above. Catching HaywardException. Please check all.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: This is never used.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: It is used on line 94.  Is there a way to let the compiler know this?

timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.author: fwolter
cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: Is this fall-through intentional?
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText:
This should be initialized during initialize() since the config may not be available at the time the handler is constructor.
But more importantly, the prop field don't seem to be needed since you can always pull the data from getThing().getProperties() as needed. There is no reason to cache it.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: see earlier comment.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: Please fix this wherever else it occurs.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: You should also include the exception message with the offline status so that users have better idea as to what went wrong.
timeline.author: cpmeister
cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: Similar code appears in many other places in this class. Please refactor the code into a separate function.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure if the core makes a copy of the properties each time you create a discovery result. So rather than making assumptions I think it would be safer to create a new HashMap each time instead of reusing it.
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: The previous code used to always get the values from index 0. Is getting the values from index i now a fix?
timeline.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: If system id is your representation property for a backyard, then this code would only be able to discover a single backyard since all backyard things would be assigned the same system id.
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: Correct.  There is only one backyard per MSP account.
